newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ share market rises 1.1 pct, hits 10-month high.
newsitem.headline: NZ share market rises 1.1 pct, hits 10-month high.

text.p: * NZ share market touches 10-month high, ends 1.1 pct up
* Fletcher Forests, Brierley gain after Forestry Corp news
* Demand generally strong, buoyed from offshore
Price movements at close
LAST CHG
320 +3 * NZSC cap index +10.94 at 4,379.50
286 nil * NZSE-10 cap index +13.11 at 1,110.73
373 nil * Volume NZ$79.5 million. Futures +5 at 1,117
682 +8 * Other movers - +8 +11
The New Zealand share market closed 1.1 percent higher on Thursday, having risen in the early afternoon to a 10-month high.
Brokers said the catalyst for the rise was feedback from the government's sale on Tuesday of Forestry Corp of New Zealand.

Two of the day's star performers were Fletcher Forests and Brierley Investments, the two New Zealand companies in the consortium which purchased FCNZ with China's Citic for $2.0 billion. BIL closed three cents up at $1.44 and Fletcher nine cents up at $1.95.
"There was a lot of offshore demand," said J.B. Were's Luke Koekoek. "It's encouraging and I would have thought there was more upside in the short-term."
The benchmark NZSE-40 capital index closed 23.78 higher at 2,199.53 but peaked at 2,207.47, its highest since October 20 last year.
The focus of the market was on the leaders, with Telecom continuing its strong performance since last week's first quarter result, up eight to $6.82, and Carter Holt Harvey up three to $3.20.
Notable laggard among the leaders was Fletcher Paper, steady on $2.86. Brokers said there is stock overhanging it.
Koekoek said it appeared that foreign investors were taking a general view of the New Zealand market.

"It was not interest rate-driven at all today. Some of these guys are just taking a New Zealand view rather than stock-specific. Most of the gains are in the heavily weighted stocks, with Fletcher Paper the exception."
He said worries about the October 12 general election had dissipated. "We have underperformed for such a long a time... people are taking the view that the worst is factored in."
